chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected pre-patellar bursitis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Take a history asking about:
    • Clinical features such as swelling and pain (site, onset, localization, exacerbating and relieving factors).
    • Risk factors for bursitis including:
      • History of trauma.
      • History of occupational or recreational activities that involve repetitive or prolonged kneeling or leaning against the knee.
      • Past medical history of systemic disease (such as rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus erythematosus) or crystal arthropathy.
    • Risk factors for septic bursitis such as:
      • Immunosuppression.
      • Alcohol excess.
      • Chronic renal failure.
      • Local corticosteroid therapy
      • Previous bursal inflammation.
    • Tetanus status — vaccinate if appropriate.
  • Examine the person looking for:
    • Systemic signs of infection or inflammation such as fever, tachycardia, hypotension and increased respiratory rate.
    • Localized swelling and erythema overlying the patella.
      • Range of knee movement is usually normal in bursitis — some discomfort may be evident at extreme flexion due to compression of the inflamed bursa.
    • Signs that may help differentiate septic bursitis from non-septic bursitis (other than fever) such as:
      • Increased warmth of skin overlying the affected bursa compared to the contralateral knee.
      • Traumatic or dermatological skin lesions overlying the bursa.
  • If the person is well and does not require admission or urgent referral, arrange investigations appropriate to the specific clinical picture, for example:
    • Diagnostic aspiration to exclude septic bursitis.
      • Aspirate should be sent for analyses including Gram stain and culture and sensitivity.
      • If there is a history of crystal arthropathy such as gout, crystal analysis should also be requested.
      • Empirical treatment with antibiotics covering gram positive skin organisms should be started while awaiting laboratory results — for further information, see the section on Management in primary care.
    • Blood tests to identify infection and inflammation such as a full blood count and inflammatory markers (for example C-reactive protein).
      • Significantly raised infective or inflammatory parameters or immunocompromise are indications for admission.
    • Imaging – if the diagnosis is unclear, or other causes of symptoms are suspected further imaging may be appropriate.
      • X-ray may identify bone lesions, spurs, osteomyelitis or joint effusion in cases of significant septic knee bursitis.
      • Ultrasound may identify abnormalities which suggest an underling cause such as loose bodies, rheumatoid nodules or gout tophi.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on how to assess a person with suspected bursitis are based on a clinical guideline from the American College of Occupational and Environmental Medicine (ACOEM) Knee disorders [ACOEM, 2011] and expert opinion in review articles [McAfee and Smith, 1988; Reid, 2010; Aaron et al, 2011; Huang, 2011; Chalmers, 2012; Baumbach et al, 2014; Hong, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].

Checking for increased warmth of the affected bursa

  • A prebursal temperature difference of 2.2°C or more may help differentiate septic from non-septic bursitis [Baumbach et al, 2014].
    • A prospective blinded study looking at cases of olecranon bursitis (n = 46, 11 septic and 35 non-septic) [Smith et al, 1989] found that a temperature difference of 2.2°C or greater between the affected and the contralateral bursae was 100 % sensitive and 94 % specific for septic bursitis.

Look for skin lesions overlying the bursa

  • Due to the superficial location of the bursa any traumatic or dermatological skin lesion (such as eczema or psoriasis) can predispose to bacterial migration into the bursal sac increasing the risk of septic bursitis [Baumbach et al, 2014].

Investigations

  • Blood tests
    • ACOEM recommend blood tests but found the supporting evidence for this recommendation to be insufficient. ACOEM do not recommend ordering a wide array of un-targeted inflammatory markers [ACOEM, 2011].
  • Imaging
    • ACOEM recommend X-ray to identify osteomyelitis or joint effusion in cases of significant septic knee bursitis but found insufficient evidence in support of this recommendation [ACOEM, 2011].
    • Expert opinion in one review article recommends that X-ray in 2 planes and ultrasound should be carried out before aspirating bursitis [Baumbach et al, 2014] — this may not be practical in primary care but may form part of assessment of pre-patellar bursitis in secondary care.
